TopicTitle: A small analysis of the effectiveness of nose cones on apoapsis altitude.

Articles.Content:
All tests done with a Rockomax BACC Solid Fuel Booster (100% thrust) and a RC-001S Remote Guidance Unit with SAS on.

"ALT" represents the altitude of the apoapsis.

---------------------------------------------------------

w/o nosecone #1: ALT=74,552

w/o nosecone #2: ALT=74,523

w/o nosecone #3: ALT=74,523

---------------------------------------------------------

w/ Standard NC #1: ALT=69,064

w/ Standard NC #2: ALT=69,062

w/ Standard NC #3: ALT=69,062

---------------------------------------------------------

w/ Aerodynamic Nose Cone #1: ALT=72,805

w/ Aerodynamic Nose Cone #2: ALT=72,806

w/ Aerodynamic Nose Cone #3: ALT=72,804

---------------------------------------------------------

w/ Protective Rocket Nose Mk7 #1: ALT=56,373

w/ Protective Rocket Nose Mk7 #2: ALT=56,369

w/ Protective Rocket Nose Mk7 #3: ALT=56,375

---------------------------------------------------------

Feel free to do you own tests with other designs to see if the results are similar or different to mine.
The nosecones add weight and drag, hence the lower apoapses. Their use lies in the fact that their drag is lower than the drag of most other parts, so they keep your rocket 'right side up'

Nosecones don't affect the drag of the whole vehicle, they just have slightly less drag themselves than a normal part. They are more for enhancing stability than for making you go faster.

If you really want to compare, go make sure that all the vehicles you're using have exactly the same mass by adding parts to make up the difference. There will be very little difference.
